TEMS Shift Tracker App

My team engineered the user interface for an app that would allow student EMS volunteers to easily communicate about getting shift coverage and reminders.

Part of a user flow diagram (Click to see the rest)

  • time range: February-April 2019
  • client: Tufts Emergency Medical Services
  • tools: Figma, Sketch, paper prototyping
  • team members: Sam Chung, Tim Holt, Anthony Tranduc

This was a semester-long group project for a Human Computer Interaction course at Tufts. Each week or so our homework would pertain to the next step in the HCI design process, with the goal of having a polished user interface prototype at the end of the semester. The class taught me a lot about the experience design process and gave me hands-on practice with a team of Human Factors & Computer Science students and a real-life client population that we interviewed and conducted usability testing sessions with.

We started by assessing the needs of the user base and defining the functions and actions that an app for swapping shifts might include. From there, we storyboarded typical examples of using the app and created low-fidelity paper prototypes of the various screens and popups.

My storyboards for sending and receiving shift swap requests (Click for full view)

Next, we spent a few weeks creating a thorough, medium-fidelity prototype in Figma. For each of these prototyping stages, our team created a video showcasing tasks one could complete on the app and also conducted usability tests with TEMS workers. During the usability tests, we asked participants to follow a Task List while Thinking Aloud and provide additional feedback and data via interviews and a post-test questionnaire.

Interactive Figma prototype; try it out!

Overall, this course has greatly informed the way I now approach user experience design prompts. It also allowed me to flex my drawing and documentation skills, and gave me exposure to the wonders of the Figma prototyping software. Thanks to Professor Jacob and to the excellent homework group #17 for being great learning partners!
